did.head: Overview
did.unittitle: Samuel Bowles papers
did.abstract: The papers include correspondence, legal documents, petitions, pamphlets, and printed material of Samuel Bowles, journalist and political activist. As editor of the influential Springfield Republican, Bowles was a prominent national voice on many public issues during the mid-nineteenth century and included in the papers is correspondence from a number of national political and business figures.

acqinfo.p: Gift of Richard Hooker, 1963. Richard Hooker donated his own papers in 1964 and the two were combined as the Bowles-Hooker Collection. This was separated into the Samuel Bowles Papers and the Richard Hooker Papers in 1979.

bioghist.head: Biographical History
bioghist.p: Samuel Bowles was born in Springfield, Massachusetts, on February 9, 1826. He was the editor of the daily edition of the Springfield Republican from 1844 to 1878. Noted for his willingness to comment on matters of political corruption, he was the subject of a libel suit. Bowles was involved in the Liberal Republican movement of 1872 and worked for the presidential nomination of Charles Francis Adams at the party's convention. He authored several books and was considered a pioneer of independent journalism. Samuel Bowles died in Springfield, Massachusetts, on January 16, 1878.

scopecontent.head: Description of the Papers
scopecontent.p: Samuel Bowles II was the second editor of the Springfield Republican, an independent provincial newspaper founded by his father on September 8, 1824. Bowles went to work on the Republican at the age of seventeen, and within a year, he was responsible for changing the paper from a weekly to a daily paper on March 27, 1844. At the Know-Nothing Convention in Philadelphia, 1855, Samuel Bowles gained national fame for himself and his newspaper.

The Samuel Bowles Papers cover the time span 1853-1890; excluding the Civil War period. During the Civil War, the paper doubled its number of subscribers, and its price went from two cents to four cents.
The period 1868-1878, is the richest, providing vivid and detailed accounts of national political and legal issues.

Bowles never hesitated in speaking out on issues of corruption or moral wrong. The famous New York Jail episode of 1868 ensured from his stand against financial swindlers. James Fisk (1834-1872) of New York issued a libel suit for $50,000 against Samuel Bowles who was seized by order of Judge McCunn and jailed in New York for one night.

Another and more famous incident described in the papers is Bowles' denunciation of James Fisk and Jay Gould (1836-1892) as thieves of the stockholders of the Eire Railroad. In this case, Bowles collided with the renowned David Dudley Field (1805-1894) who according to Bowles, could not honorably defend such clients as Fisk and Gould. The published correspondence and letters congratulating Bowles on his stand on the moral issue of the rights and duties of counsel are in this collection.

Bowles' steadfast convictions are best shown in the Liberal Republican movement of 1872. Ample correspondence from Carl Schurz (1829-1906) and some from Horace White (1834-1916) shows the movement in its formation and end. Bowles worked long hours for the presidential nomination of Charles Francis Adams (1807-1886) at this convention; yet he supported Horace Greeley (1811-1872) who was nominated. Information on the Liberal Republican movement of 1872 may be found in the 1872 and 1876 files of the collection.

The Bowles Papers are rich in correspondence from eminent personages of the 1860s and 1870s. Henry Laurens Dawes (1816-1903), James Gillespie Blaine (1830-1893), Nathaniel Prentiss Banks (1825-1894), and Newton Booth (1825-1892) all have large numbers of letters in the collection.

Henry Laurens Dawes, a representative and senator from Massachusetts, was responsible for the Dawes Act of 1887. This act allows individual Indians to own land within reservations and gives citizenship to competent Indians. Dawes helped build a method of Indian education and put Indians under federal criminal law protection. The warm political and personal friendship of Bowles and Dawes is apparent in the many letters containing abundant political agreement as well as exchange of ideas.

The James Gillespie Blaine correspondence is at quite an opposite pole from the Dawes relationship. In 1869, Blaine and Dawes were opponents for the position of Speaker of the United States House of Representatives. Dawes was defeated by Blaine in a contest which Bowles believed Blaine to have won through a coalition with the notorious Benjamin Franklin Butler (1818-1893). An exchange of letters over this issue between Bowles and Blaine forms an interesting part of this collection.

Samuel Bowles did not allow family ties to stand in his way. In 1874, he opposed his brother-in-law, Henry Alexander, Jr., for Congress, because he believed that Alexander's health was not strong enough for the strain. Alexander and Bowles were never reunited. Bowles fired his younger brother, Benjamin Franklin Bowles, from the Republican counting room due to inadequacy for the job. Benjamin died in 1876 in Paris.

Samuel Bowles II is a great figure in the history of American journalism, whose political influence and favor were coveted and feared by the leading thinkers of America during the 1860s and 1870s. He pushed the Springfield Republican, a provincial Massachusetts newspaper, to national prominence, thus establishing a precedent in journalism. A glance at the following list of Bowles' correspondents shows the value of the collection to the history of the United States in the nineteenth century.

The series is arranged chronologically. Researchers should consult the "Descriptive Catalogue of Manuscripts" at the end of the finding aid, which provides an item level description of each letter in this series.

scopecontent.p: The "Descriptive Catalogue of Manuscripts" consists of an item level description of all letters in the collection. The correspondence itself is located in boxes 1 and 2 in Series I. Researchers can use this index to find relevant materials and then can use the inventory in Series I to determine the specific box that holds the materials.

did.unittitle: Correspondence
Brooks Adams writes Bowles that an audience did not go well at Troy and says that he would like to see Bowles.
Brooks Adams gives a severe indictment of Hayes; he suggests he should be deposed.
Charles Francis Adams thanks Bowles for a kindness paid him in the Republican. He does not consider himself a public figure.
Charles Francis Adams had gone to N.Y. to see his father off on a trip. He discusses a letter written by his father about Wells which was printed in the Republican. He says Bowles has a sure thing.

Charles Francis Adams writes again to correct his statement of his father's that he did not think Wells would relish his letter. Adams is much interested in the game between Wells and his father. He believes that is will help the Cincinnati convention.
Charles Francis Adams tells Bowles that he made a good fight for his father. Even though he was defeated, he said that Greeley had not been calculated.
Charles Francis Adams, Jr.,cannotagree with Bowles on an unstated point. He says he wishes he could. He writes Bowles to show him different logic.
Adams acknowledges a note received from Bowles at Quincy. He points out that railroads do not have clerical force in the commissions and that press abstracts are made by the railroads' own reporters.
Charles Francis Adams, Jr., rebukes Bowles for his columns on railroads.
Charles Francis Adams, Jr., writes Bowles that he is going to Kansas City and wonders if Bowles will meet him at the train going through Springfield.
Charles Francis Adams, Jr., requests a talk with Bowles.
Charles Francis Adams, Jr., discusses the Tweed Ring and considers it deplorable that it was attempted to connect Tilden.
Charles Francis Adams. Jr., discusses briefly the railroad commissioners in Massachusetts, and mentions some problems he cannot at present discuss with Bowles.
Henry Adams requests Bowles to help a friend find a paper mill, despite Adams being for Tilden in the presidential election.
Amelia P. Alexander writes Bowles that she is pleased with the result of an election of her brother, Henry, but they are hurt beyond repair over articles published in the Republican.

Henry Alexander Jr. encloses a bill for taxes paid for Bowles. He says that his health is bad. Alexander says that if the joint ownership of land is to continue, it must be let to someone. He says that he would prefer merely dividing the property. He states that the disagreementbetween themis not the cause for this.
Allen discusses the political influence of the Republican.
Charles Allen reports to Bowles that he does not know of the changes proposed in the judicial system.
Mary Clemmer Ames thanks Bowles for the generous notice of the novel, Victoire, in the Republican. She laments also her brother and husband in the war and curses the Rebels.

Mary Clemmer Ames speaks to Bowles of her poem which appeared in the Republican. She says that it is not to be confused with the partisan orations at Woodstock. She speaks of Blaine as being utterly selfish.
Four fragments of letters from Mary Clemmer Ames

Banks is going to write Lincoln on the subject of Warren's appointment. He will transmit a letter from Sam G. Ward in favor of a Mr. Hooper with his own approval. He compliments the Republican on being an excellent paper.
Banks thanks Bowles for articles relating to the business of the legislature.
Banks agrees with the political position of the He discusses Boutwell as one fully possessed of his views.
Banks tells Bowles that he will be happy to talk with him about the "popularsovereigntydogma." He thinks it is fine for Kansas but not for Utah.
Banks speaks of Gov. Chase as the guest of honor at an enthusiastic reception and Jefferson Davis as being impudent.
Banks proposes a trip to the West with Sam.
Banks expresses pleasure that Wentworth and Cushing will give just and hearty support to honest measures. He describes Lincoln as being happy.
Banks merely states that he is pessimistic as all men are now.
Banks is sorry that Bowles has sciatica and that they cannot journey to Europe together. After having read the Inaugural, he fears that Virginia will secede.
Banks encloses a note from a Mr. Briggs discussing a "mystery."
Banks says that the California delegation will be first for Seward.
Benjamin Fordyce Barker sends a check to Bowles for copies of the Republican with pleasure. He says that he reads the more than any other paper.
Francis Channing Barlow speaks of an agreement with Bowles and a congratulations for his treatment of Field.
Agnes Bartlett thanks Bowles for his friendship to her husband who is now dead.
W. F. Bartlett writes Bowles that he has read that Dawes stumped Butler's district for him. He hopes that Dawes will not get Sumner's senate seat.

Frank Bartlett had been asked to make an address at Lexington of the same sort as his Harvard speech. He fears, however, that he cannot say much on the subject of the North and South without offending his host.
Bartlett writes Bowles that he is glad to support a candidate like Adams.
W. F. Bartlett sends Bowles a copy of a speech which he made at Haverhill for the opening of a new public library.
Bartlett said he did not know of the conference until too late to let Bowles know anything, but he trusts that they will not select such a man as Blaine.

William E. Barton writes to Waldo S. Cook, Republican editor, a letter discussing Josiah G. Holland as the writer of a Republican editorial, Nov. 21, 1863, on the Gettysburg Address. A letter from Cook to Richard Hooker suggests that the above listed letter should be kept in the Republican collection.
A. W. Beard wishes to discuss some matters of state policy with Bowles when he comes to Boston.
Beard is pleased with a letter which he received from Bowles. He tells Bowles he has been in agreement with the Republican on state matters.
Henry Ward Beecher tells Bowles his reasons for not seeing him.
Annie Kennedy Bidwell writes Bowles that she is sending him a copy of the Sacramento Record Union, especially thanking him for the interest taken in their Independent Movement.
Anna Bigelow wants to know if Bowles approves of an article in the Apr 27 Republican entitled "Mr. Moody's Work in Boston.
John Bigelow gives Bowles his opinion on the state of politics at this time. The opinion comes as a result of Bowles' suggestion for New York hearing Charles Francis Adams.
John Bigelow questions what is the matter with the Republican and wonders for what vagaries Bowles is holding Tilden responsible.
Billings expresses sorrow at the death of Bowles' mother.
Billings tells of a change in plans for July.
Billings has had an attack, and the letter is a discussion of his illness.
Billings thanks Bowles for his kind letter and discussed his family.
Billings tells Bowles that he has been under the weather a few days, but he wants to thank Bowles for a compliment.
Billings congratulates Bowles on a victory. He says that it is bad for Phelps but that Endicott thoroughly sustained Bowles. He says that absolute justice was not nearly done.
Billings tells Bowles of sleeping sitting up with his feet in warm water.
Billings tells of his health. He has had some good days. He speaks of Dawes as almost doing too much.
F.W. Bird writes Bowles a congratulatory letter on his trial.
F.W. Bird has a certain testimonial up to $5,000 and is trying to get to $5,000 net.

Blaine requests copies of articles printed in the Republican on his conduct in the House Speakership Contest. The articles indicated that Blaine was censored by H. L. Dawes for his conduct. Blaine expresses surprise.
Blaine accosts Bowles for not naming fact in the offense of Bowles' "fastidious notions." He disavows all that Bowles claimed in the Republican.

Blaine states that his reply to Bowles was merely a response to a former Bowles letter and to the erroneous statements in the Republican. Blaine cannot justify what he considers an assault on his character.
Blaine asks for the return of his letter and says that he will return Bowles'. He merely repeats that he did not break political ethics and neither did Dawes. He hopes they will be friends.
Blaine requests Bowles to dine with him.
Blaine sends information on the House Committee to Bowles as a favor for Republican publication.

Blaine says that some editor of the Republican is pointing out all of the bad points of the 1875 Maine campaign. Blaine speaks of bitter remarks made in the about him and Lot M. Morrill. (Blaine was appointed to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Morrill and took his seat Dec. 4, 1876.)

Blaine asks Bowles not to become adamant about one of his letters published in the Boston Journal until he had completely looked the matter over. He says that Henry Wilson's temperament was bad. (Wilson died Nov. 22, 1875.)
Blaine gives Bowles a scathing opinion of Charles Francis Adams and the entire Adams family and asks Bowles to print it.

George Bliss, attorney for the southern district of New York, begins his letter to Bowles with an article pasted on a letter concerning the blunders at the district attorney's office on the prosecution of Woodhull and Claflin's Weekly . He is very critical of the writers of the Republican and he considers the article an example of Republican criticism. He says that he is not a critic of the Republican but he does not want to be misused by a man who claims to be his friend.
Booth wonders if his decisions concerning railroads will make him unpopular and unlikely to be re-elected.
He agrees with Bowles' advice to go slow on the railroads, as they do not want them in the hands of the government, which would then be a monarchy in everything but name.
Booth discusses thepossibilityof his being elected a U.S. senator.
Booth denies talk of his resignation as governor. He says that he has a good legislature and is making progress on the railroads.
The railroad people have beaten Booth in the Senate. Booth feels that the Independent Movement in Oregon will work. He feels that Grant has held more trumps than any man living.
Booth discusses a fishing trip with Bowles.
Booth discusses California politics, especially the politician, Jones.
Booth says that the Army Appropriations Bill is before Congress. A controversy exists over the Hayes' cabinet. He thanks Bowles for a sketch of him on his vocabulary.
Booth congratulates Bowles on the result of the Phelps libel suit. He speaks again of Pacheco for governor of California.
Booth discusses the California Gubernatorial race of 1875 in the light of Miller, Pacheco, and Gorham.
Booth discusses thepossibilityin 1875 as to whether the Republican vote will dominate.
Booth has read his official nomination for senator.
Booth does not think that the stability of the British Consulcan be questioned.
Booth laments a certain amount of inconsistency in the Republican. He states he that he has not seen people whom he likes since Bowles' departure.

Booth discusses the French as being theoretical and the Anglo Saxon as being perfect. Lot M. Morrill made a speech in which Booth says he doesn't know that domestic debts and credits of a company must be equal.

Booth speaks of a near scene in the Senate. A speech was made by Boutwell which Booth believed to be an attempt to be as offensive as possible. The speech was bidding against Blaine and the slavery question.
Newton Booth discusses the congressionalsituation in the U.S. in 1876 with Bowles.
Booth thinks that Bowles will like Richard James Oglesby more now, since he knows him. Booth feels that Blaine of Maine is losing his popularity.
Newton Booth tells Bowles that Grant is one who takes a superficial view of Lincoln's character.
Booth wonders where the U.S. would have been today without John Brown. Booth believes a need exists for John Brown today. He indicates that no one is sincere.

Booth corrects an article in the Republican that says that an amendment first made by his was afterwards defeated. His defeat was on the amendment of the second section. Booth says that this put him in a false position with Dawes, and Dawes made unkind remarks in a speech.
Booth speaks of a meeting of the Republican and the T. H.
Booth informs Bowles that he has scarcely a hope of carrying the legislature, especially since Aaron Augustus Sargent is a candidate.
Bowles discusses in this unascribed letter the position of the Phelps suit against the Republican [copy]

Bowles grants Blaine's request of affairs in the Republican. Bowles states that he believes Blaine's "taste and modes of political advancement" are quite different than the fastidious ones of the Republican and Mr. Dawes. Bowles tells Blaine that he has sinned against his own personal self.

Bowles points out that Blaine's letter of March 24 was "inexcusable, ill-tempered, and insulting." Bowles said that their personal relationship was now cut off and that he would make the most of Blaine's mistakes.

Bowles states a few reasons why he considers Blaine's actions in the Speakership Contest as having shown impropriety: Blaine personally solicited votes and Blaine personally superintended the election.

Bowles returns the letter of March 24 to Blaine and states that it is all that stands between personal friendship with Blaine; Bowles mentions the Speakership Contest againbutagrees to hold it in abeyance.

Bowles tells J. C. Collins that he has read a letter and speech from him with interest. He says that he will be in Cincinnati as a journalist. Bowles feels that the reform needed in the country is to unite the best men of both parties.

Bowles points out to Sumner the cowards who deny theiraffiliationwith independence, as Alley. He hopes that they can all be together, or otherwise the reform movement must go outside the Republican Party. He says that Fenton will sell if he can get his price. He tells Sumner that he cannot escape his responsibility for coming out against Grant.

Bowles writes Benjamin Gratz Brown that he will be in Cincinnati as a journalist only. He said that he had not in many years taken personal part in the parties. He believes that perhaps the Cincinnati nomination will fall on Adams.

Bowles writes Richard Dudley Hubbard that he feels sorry for all of the bad things said about Hubbard, after receiving a letter from him. Bowles feels that he has refrained from too many of the good things. He tells Hubbard that he abandoned Connecticut when he saw it was going for Grant.
Bowles discusses the presidential candidates other than Grant at Philadelphia or Greeley at Baltimore.

Bowles tells Charles Sumner that the Republican, of course, had no authority in a matter of moral consciousness. Bird at Cincinnati has boasted that he defeated the Adams nomination. Bowles charges that this came straight from him. Bowles says that to him Sumner and Trumbull would have been an ideal ticket, and that Adams was above the Cincinnati movement.
Bowles defends his believe in Greeley as a presidential candidate; he cannot comply with Olmstead's opinion of Greeley.

Bowles writes Henry Laurens Dawes that he thinks Greeley has great possibilities in him for the coming election. He said that in several previous monthsWashingtonhad had the power to change things; now he believes that events will be in control.
Bowles continues his own view of Greeley, but he admits that Olmstead's beliefs of Greeley as "humbug" contain some truth.

Samuel Bowles writes Henry Laurens Dawes that he cannot say he has the courage to make the fight but will in his independent way. He says that he wanted Adams but accepted Greeley, since he is better than Grant. He wants to know what impression Bridgman had made upon Dawes.
Bowles writes Carl Schurz that he wrote to Bullock and is not disappointed. He does not think Bullock's signature for the Cincinnati convention is necessary.
Bowles tells Allen Thayer that in the distribution of the sheep and goats that he understands that Thayer is going with the goats.

Bowles tells George Bliss that he seems to be spoiling for a fight with him. Bowles admits that perhaps the Republican misinterpreted the character of a Judge Blatchford; Bowles believes that his newspaper had an incomplete story. Bowles tells Bliss that the Republican has always avoided severe comments on Bliss. He says, on the contrary, that Bliss has made severe comments on the Republican.
Bowles rebukes Russell for writing a "charming monograph" which had such a eulogistic style that he asked him where Achilles was.

This letter from Bowles is unascribed. Bowles says that now he has letters of Josiah Clarkin hand. The request that Clark's letters be printed seems unreasonable to him. He will not publish it. [copy]
Samuel Bowles writes Henry Alexander a letter requesting Alexander not to run for Congress because of his bad health. He tells him that he will have to oppose him politically if he does.

Bowles writes John Wells that it is complimentary to be thought worthy of discipline by such as Wells. He thinks that he was not unjust to Phelps. Bowles thinks a wide field for judiciary reform is possible.
Bowles answers Rieman on Mr. Reed by describing Reed as an honest, hard working preacher, but not an intellectual.

Bowles writes C. B. Morrill that the making of a platform for Maine Democrats should wait until after the presidential nominations. He thinks it should at least wait until it is seen whether Blaine would make a contest for Morrill's place in the Senate.
Bowles has a draft for a letter to Joseph H. Rieman recommending a Mr. Reid for a Presbyterian church.
Bowles expresses a wish to see Carl Shurz. He discusses the conference and hopes it will be a success.

Bowles writes George Washburn Smalley that there is nothing much new. He says that the Republican has made a commended place for itself. On the other hand, he believes that the Tribune has lost a great opportunity. Bowles says that the old distrust for Tilden is gone.
Bowles tells Musgrave that he is not at all well, but he does hope to meet Halstead in New York. He tells Musgrave that if he is a man of peace, why did he slap poor Jennings' face.
Bowles write Alexander Turney Stewart and expresses disappointment that Cox was not made chairman of Ways and Means. He also discusses railroad disputes of the day.

Bowles tells Allen Thayer that he did not mean to seem contemptuous. Bowles said that he did not think that Thayer was pledged to Adams, but he did think that he was absolutely independent. Afterwards, Bowles had strong evidence that Thayer was working for Rice.
Anna Callender Brackett, educator, has had a poem published in Harper's. She wonders if Bowles will make some copies for her.
Anna Callender Brackett writes a thank you to Bowles for publishing a poem of hers; she also gives a description of a recent trip.
Lizzia Branciard wants to know if Bowles knows of anyone who would need a correspondent such as she to attend the Paris Exposition.
H. O. Bristadt thanks Bowles for a copy of the Republican.
Benjamin Gratz Brown tells Bowles that he had read a telegram and could see that Bowles would be with them in Cincinnati.
Chamberlain thanks Bowles for his kindness expressed in the Republican. He tells Bowles that he has been able to see some reasons for doubt.

Chamberlain writes Bowles that he hopes Grant will declare himself on their side. He says that sight could not be lost of the fact that they are Southern not Northern Republicans. He expressed admiration for Bowles' independent course.
Chester Williams Chapin gives an expression of the dull time of politics and an unenthusiastic reception of the Cincinnati candidate.

Josiah Clark writes George Merriam a letter which identifies Merriam as the author of an article called "Candor." The article concerns the Beecher trial. Clark condemned the Republican as being "gossipy."
Mary Clemmer writes Bowles thanking him for his kind friendship and for a photograph book.

Phoebe W. Couzins writes Bowles remembering a very pleasant visit by him in St. Louis. Bowles has said he will mention items of her "pen and tongue." She sends him a copy of "Ballot Box," published in Toledo on behalf of women.
Isaac Curry of Richmond, Virginia, calls Bowles' attention to an article he has written on "Executive Patronage of Civil Service."
Richard Henry Dana, Jr., tells Bowles that he has dealt exactly right with the delicate subject of legal tenders.
Richard Henry Dana, Jr., is overwhelmed with congratulations on a stand which the Republican took on a law suit.
Richard Henry Dana, Jr., tells Bowles why he did not vote for Greeley.
Richard Henry Dana, Jr., asks Bowles to reprint an article.
Sam Davis tells Bowles of his bouts with rheumatism and briefly discusses David Ames Wells.
Henry Laurens Dawes is giving Bowles his views onprohibitorylaw. He thinks the law is a gross mistake.

Henry Laurens Dawes is enjoying a vacation and apologizes for not having seen Bowles in so long. Dawes has seen the Blaine correspondence and is surprised at Blaine's denial of the problem of the Speakership Contest. He says in that case half of the House must be liars.

Henry Laurens Dawes writes to Bowles, pondering on reasons that he has not heard from Bowles in so long. He tells Bowles that he knows he was dissatisfied with the way the convention went. He thinks that Bowles is wrong about Fenton, for he believes Fenton was for Greeley all along.
Dawes discusses the Wool and Woolens Tariff of 1868 and commends Bowles on his philosophy in politics.
Dawes congratulates Mr. and Mrs. Bowles on their twenty-fifth wedding anniversary.
Dawes discusses a speech of his own about which he has received many letters; he congratulates Bowles on his ability to make "glorious fights."

Dawes is discouraged with the Republican Party and compares the present administration with the Gladstone Ministry in England; he believes that the Republican Party can be saved by the "folly of its opponents."
Dawes tells Bowles that he is one of the few people who think of him now except in connection with the tariff.
Dawes thanks Bowles for his support against the Sanborn Contracts.
Dawes again speaks of an affair with John D. Sanborn and talks also of a man named Sam Hooker.

Dawes is especially unhappy as he writes this letter to Bowles. He feels that he is called "weak" when he has to make certain decisions. Dawes fears that he and Bowles are drawn apart: Bowles by journalistic apostates and Dawes by political friends.

Dawes discusses his own future in politics: a. He thinks that he will not be needed after the state is saved. b. He wonders why the Republicans have elected Pierce, Harris, Stevens, and Talbot. c. He asks Bowles to deal with George D. Robinson, and he will deal with John Randolph Tucker of Virginia.
Dawes writes Bowles that affairs in Washington are especially bad. He says that the Currency Bill was forced through without the chance of an amendment. He thinks that Phil Sheridan always blunders.
Dawes thanks Bowles for a good article about him in the Republican. He says that he tries to love his enemies, but the fellows in the West make it difficult.
Dawes says that Bowles' idea of the Congressional situation is purely as an outsider.
Dawes is ashamed of the conditions in Washington at this time; he is afraid it is the death of the Republican Party.
Dawes writes of Benjamin F. Butler, saying he is a man who likes to see things smashed up generally.
Dawes discusses Richard Henry Dana, Jr., as a man who doesn't have much common sense.
Dawes explains to Bowles that he cannot interfere with the election of delegates from Massachusetts.
Dawes speaks of a certain amount of "dirty work" done by Newton Booth of California, as well as his influence with Tilden.
Dawes briefly mentions Frelinghuysen. He cites the fall of Adam and the landing of the Pilgrims as the two greatest calamities that ever befell man.

Walker accuses a man named Traps of being a cabinet maker and anupholsterer, as related by Dawes. Dawes discusses the controversy between himself and James G. Blaine regarding the House Speakership Contest of 1869.
M. D. Defrees discusses with Bowles the presidential possibilities of 1876.
Defrees discusses the possible Republican and Democratic candidates with Bowles. He thinks that the Republicans will nominate either Blaine of Conkling.
Defrees thanks Bowles for some Republican articles. He tells Bowles that he is wrong about the position of a Morrison.
Defrees says that the name of Judge Davis cannot be presented at the St. Louis convention with his consent.
Anna E. Dickinson congratulates Bowles on being a "good" hater. She discusses the possibility of going to England and hopes Bowles will write her there.
Anna E. Dickinson sent a pamphlet to Bowles to be published in Springfield.
Matthew Paul Drady expresses to Bowles preference for Adams in the forthcoming election. He says his Republican convention had expressed some preference for Blaine.
Matthew Paul Drady tells Bowles of a commencement address which he made at Wallamet University.

Matthew Paul Drady thanks Bowles for his kind remarks to the graduating class of Salem. He comments on Hayes as doing pretty well considering the atmosphere. He says that Sherman is a machine man in the cabinet.
Duclay writes Murat Halstead that force was not used in a Mississippi problem. He says that Bowles wants Charles Francis Adams, Jr., not Mr. Halstead.
William Greenleaf Eliot sends Bowles a copy of an inaugural address of Washington University, St. Louis. He feels the need for a university in the West and would like to appeal for Boston wealth.
William Maxwell Evarts acknowledges a note from Bowles and apologizes for being unable to make a proposed speech.
David Dudley Field acknowledges a letter received from Bowles and wishes him better luck next time for a cause.
Henry Martyn Field, editor of the N.Y. Evangelist, , had published conspicuously some material for Bowles.
Forbes writes Bowles that he is correct in setting Dawes right in a false position. He wishes that Dawes would defend himself in a position sadly misunderstood.
Forbes discusses Butler with Bowles whom he believes is not so smart as he should be.
Forbes hopes Bowles will call attention to a Mr. Pope in the Republican.
John Murray Forbes writes Bowles that Judge Hoar has not the faculty of conciliating men.
Gardner informs Bowles that he is not thin-skinned.
Gardner acknowledges Bowles' note and says that he values the praise of the legislature very highly. He tells Bowles that the modified personal liberty bill was never printed.

Henry Joseph Gardner seconds a commission to Bowles as payment of his respect. He has had a letter from Governor Johnson saying he had not received his due. He wants Bowles to send him a Republican copy to give him a "puff."

Gardner says he was sorry not to see Bowles on a certain day. He tells of his loyalties at a Philadelphia convention to General Wilson. Gardner feels there are those who want him out of office and wants Bowles' feelings on it.
Gardner tells Bowles that he has no patience with him on his tortuous course against him.
Gardner points out that there was a Republican article that was very vindictive towards him.
Gardner points out that he has received no letter from Bowles.
Gardner thanks Bowles for a letter, but he tells him that he will have to be more specific about "recognized friends."
Gardner discusses a question raised by some gentlemen from New York. He questions whether members of the council should be bound by a majority. This letter is unascribed.

James A. Garfield writes David Ames Wells and thanks him for the perusal of a Bowles' letter. He says that Bowles is mistaken in his association with Blaine - that he has wanted no one to ask favors for him. Garfield states that actually he would like a free lance in the House rather than running a committee. He says that he is disgusted with politics.
Washington Gladden discussed with Bowles the criticism of Henry Chandler Bowen, ad manager of the Independent.
L. N. Goodell thanks Bowles for sending him certain information. The letter contains a discussion of a Mr. Gustafson who is discussed as being affable when he likes.
Lessie Goodell Gustafson writes Bowles to discoverwhathe can of Alexis Gustafson, a deserter from the U.S. Signal Service.
Richard B. Gwin compliments Bowles on a good article in the Republican. He is especially impressed with Bowles' insistence on honor.
Richard B. Gwin says that it is worth writing to Bowles when we get such good response. He says he hopes never to meet Dawes again.
Susan Hab relates to Bowles that she has written to Caroline Briggs about the matter of the Old South and relates this to Bowles.
E. B. Haskell wonders if Bowles can help him by any letter to the inside of the newspaper business in London or Paris.
E. B. Haskell said that he spent three days in Washington at Bowles' suggestion. He had an interview with Sumner and interesting talks with various Washington dignitaries.
Joseph Roswell Hawley tells Bowles that he was in Washington when he received his letter, or he would have answered it sooner. He says that he would like to be senator.
Joseph Roswell Hawley said he has never seen so many lies as Senator Smith has told about the U.S. Centennial Commission.
Joseph Roswell Hawley writes to Bowles for advice on the fact that the Connecticut delegation has decided to nominate Marshall Jewell for president.

Joseph Roswell Hawley has read in the Republican of the foolishness and meanness of the Republican in assailing Landers for non-attendance at sessions of Congress. He tells Bowles that Landers answered 8 roll calls out of about 106. He points out to Bowles that Landers is only noted as a dodger.

Rutherford Birchard Hayes encloses a paragraph from the Republican in his letter, which holds Hayes responsible for appointing George H. Butler to special post office agency in the Black Hills. Hayes replies to Bowles that the paragraph was a total mistake. He says that he never heard of the position until Butler was appointed. He tells Bowles that "placating" was not his way and that he only tried to do what was right.

Thomas Wentworth Higginson has just read a budget of notices from a book sent by a Mr. Pitman. He said that the notices were cruel and tells Bowles that he should change the name of Across the Continent to A Voyage Around the World. World.
Roswell Dwight Hitchcock thanks Bowles for a copy of the Republican.
Josiah Gilbert Holland discusses with Bowles the purchase of stock in the Republican and his respect for the friendship of Samuel Bowles.
Josiah Gilbert Holland sends Bowles condolences on the death of his brother, Ben.
Isabella Beecher Hooker writes Bowles asking him to tell her his views on Britain before going home.
Isabella Hooker proposes a necessary meeting between the Bowles and the Hookers in Hartford or Springfield.
Isabella Beecher Hooker writes to Bowles concerning Connecticut on woman suffrage. She discusses a bill drawn up by her husband, Richard, on suffrage and a speech which she made in the State Senate.
Isabella Hooker writes Bowles that she has now found the proceedings of the Woman's Rights Convention held at Seneca Falls, New York, July, 1848.
Alice S. Hooper writes a letter to Bowles with an enclosure (which was not in the letter) and discusses the enclosure in congruency with a policy of Great Britain.
Julia Ward Howe writes Bowles a note on justice for the dead.
Hubbard thanks Bowles for his very generous treatment of him and states that if he is defeated in the election the Republican will be largely responsible.

Hubbard congratulates Bowles on the choice of Dana as counsel. He praises Bowles on his discriminating criticism; yet he thinks politics are corrupt and does not understand how Charles Sumner could have remained upright.
Richard Dudley Hubbard congratulates Bowles on a law suit, telling him he would have been victorious except for a small technicality.

Edmund Hudson writes Bowles that he understands that the Republican has information that George H. Butler was not appointed by the cabinet. Hudson says his information came from a member of the cabinet. Hudson says that Talbot of Maine has been replaced. He has talked to Sherman about the latter; he says that Talbot was one of the few Maine Republicans who had not bowed his knee to Blaine. He related that Bret Harte was in Georgetown, poverty stricken.
Frederick Dan Huntington writes Bowles an article to be reprinted in the Republican.
Huntington writes that he appreciated Bowles' approval of his work at Emmanuel Church, Boston, and as deacon of Trinity Church.
W. H. Huntington writes to Bowles of Smalley and personal relations.
W. H. Huntington writes to a Mr. Wells. He says that he came across in reading an instance on paper currency. He sends it along with thanks for a new copy of Robinson Crusoe.
Marietta Hutchinson writes Bowles a note of congratulations on his daughter's marriage. She says she has lost contact with many old friends and hopes to see the Bowles again.
F. B. Jackson expresses regret at the death of Bowles' brother.
Helen Hunt Jackson asks Bowles to come to Colorado.
Helen Hunt Jackson writes Bowles that they are now at their home in Princeton and again asks Bowles to come visit.
Helen Hunt Jackson writes an apology to Bowles that they will not be able to meet Bowles due to a complication of plans.
Helen Hunt Jackson writes Mrs. Bowles, asking the Bowles to come visit them in Colorado Springs.

William Sharpless Jackson sends a note of apology to Bowles for not having answered a query. He wants Bowles to come to Colorado for a volley around June 1. Helen Hunt Jackson adds a postscript on her husband's masculine way of putting things.
Jewell tells Bowles of various places he will be traveling. He invites Bowles to eat with him in the Massasoit.
Jewell confirms an engagement to meet Bowles and tells Bowles to invite the kind of people he likes.
Jewell said he has told the Post to dry up. He points out that Booth said a good thing about Blaine. He says he had a nice letter from Schurz.
Jewell invites Bowles to come and dine.
Jewell says that Friday will be a good day, and he will be at home. He tells Bowles that he will meet him at the train.

Oliver Johnson tells Bowles that he cannot understand what he had done that would cause him to be stigmatized as an infidel by the Republican. He says that the name Christian has covered all the radicalism he knows.

Johnson writes Bowles that he understands that Bowles did not mean to call him an infidel but that the vast number of orthodox people would takeit inthe extreme. He also wants to know if there is a good country journal of which he can have control.
Oliver Johnson wants to know why the Republican lends its columns to such unscrupulous papers as the Brooklyn Review and the New York Sun.
Barton S. Jones, a correspondent of the Indianapolis Journal, encloses an accompanying article on Senator Mortin, which he could not have published at his home.
G. I. Jones, publisher, writes Bowles a letter of agreement with the choice of Charles Francis Adams for president in 1876.
C. P. Kimball discusses with Bowles an orator at Cincinnati. Bowles and Kimball want Charles Francis Adams.
Rose G. Kingsley hopes Bowles will be kindly disposed toward her cousin, W. Leighton Hope-Edwards, who will visit the states.
L. Q. C. Lamar sends Bowles a telegram saying that Blaine had approved and advises a mission of Lamar's. He tells Bowles to modify his criticism so that the people can hear.

Perry Arthur Latham discusses with Bowles the prominence given to Walker's speech at Amherst. Latham thinks that Walker deserves praise, but he also says that some of the ideas were original in a book of his.
Richard Lathus sends a thank you for a letter. He says to Bowles that liberal-minded men scarcely change politics or religion.

Richard Lathus found favor from Bowles at the Manhattan Club. He discusses the hospitality between South Carolina and Massachusetts on a social occasion. He feels a decadence in political moral convictions.
Lodge gives a report on the activities of the Republican Party at this time with a discussion of the National Convention.

Henry Cabot Lodge was assistant editor of the North American Review when this letter was written. He states that they are trying to do work in the Republican Party as Bowles had. He does not want the party to have to go back to the Independent Movement.
Lodge is issuing invitations to an undesignated event.
Henry Cabot Lodge thanks Bowles for his foresight in the Senate paralysis. He asks for help from Bowles on the subject of taxation.
S. Maltby acknowledges a letter from Bowles; he says that Spaulding would be good but he cannot afford a campaign.
R. H. Mathus thanks Bowles for writing an admirable article on the president of Amherst.
William Gordon McCabe calls to Bowles' mind a pleasant voyage across the Atlantic, which they shared. He suggests an exchange between the Index of Petersburg, Virginia, and the Republican.
George S. Merriam sends Bowles a copy of his book, .
Merriam acknowledges a letter from Bowles. He indicates knowledge of a Bowles trip to Kentucky and Colorado.
Merriam tells Bowles that one must go abroad to know what a good paper the Republican was.
George S. Merriam first writes an apology for having taken so much of Bowles' time on the twenty-fifth. Merriam says that his family has been hurt by the Republican attitude towards Beecher.
Donald Grant Mitchell (Ik Marvel) wants a copy of the semi-weekly Republican.
John B. Morgan in Paris apologizes to Bowles for not having been able to see his brother before he lost.
John Lothrop Motley apologizes to Bowles for being late in the receipt of the copy of Across the Continent.
Musgrave writes Bowles that he had gone to Gov. Morgan's reception for Halstead of Cincinnati. He says that he found it cold and formal.
Thomas Nast had looked for Bowles' name announcing his arrival in Washington but could not find it. He apologizes for not having gone on a proposed excursion, but his work kept him.
Nordhoff tells Bowles that he too believes in Hayes.
Nordhoff has just returned from Washington, as he writes this letter to Bowles. He discusses the fact that Springfield does not have a standard line to New York.
Nordhoff speaks to Bowles of his children. He states that the Republican has been good to them.
Nordhoff speaks in pity to Bowles, since Blaine has made such a hit with the country.
Nordhoff tells Bowles that he forgot to mail him a book on the George T. Davis obituary.
The grain war has just finished, and Nordhoff asks Bowles if he has ever swung the deceitful scythe.
Nordhoff points out the slowness of Hayes to Bowles. He says that Hayes always thinks that tomorrow is another day. He fears that the country is going to pieces.
Nordhoff relates that Bartlett gave him an account of Bowles, and that he is worried about him.

Charles Eliot Norton writes Bowles that he has a sermon which was delivered in the first parish of Springfield, Oct 16, 1775. He says that it contains historical narrative on early Springfield and wants to know if Bowles cares to reprint it.
Francis W. Palfrey talks of a fund for Bartlett's family. He thinks that the fund should not be made public.
Elizabeth L. Parker thanks Bowles for being kind during her mother's death.
John Pierce thanks Bowles for a kind remembrance.
Robert Pomeroy thanks Bowles for a tribute to Seth Pomeroy.
W. M. Pomeroy has discussed with Bowles a possible candidate for Congress and is thus far disappointed.
A. K. Potter discusses a news article with Bowles, containing a personal reference to the Phelps affair.
Thomas R. Potter acknowledges a letter from Bowles. He had not had a reply of the U.S. on certain unmentioned questions, but he felt safe due to the good will of Americans.
N. Price tells Bowles that he is too good and mean to spoil him. He speaks of an interview at the N.Y. Tribune which was Halstead's doing.
N. A. Priest writes Bowles of a Miss Stebbins who has not had experience teaching.

E. Armstrong Reed returns a letter sent to her by Griffin or Bowles. She says that the letter is kind in its expressions against her and says the false impression of Mr. Bowles to personal friends shall be removed.
Alexander Hamilton Rice tells Bowles that he has read the Republican and that Bowles has a progressive view of the state. He congratulates him on being discriminating and candid.
B. Rice tells Bowles that a spiel on clerical education was not kindly received.
Lizzie D. Rice writes Bowles that she did not look for unexpected congratulations on correspondent work. She discussed Branciard, whom she is going to marry.
Abby Faye Richardson thanks Bowles for his friendship to her and her husband.
Runkle jokingly discusses some domestic problems with Bowles.
Runkle discusses women's suffrage with Bowles and speaks briefly of the Grant administration.
Runkle speaks of the Republican to Bowles and a certain Mr. Colfax.
This Runkle letter is incomplete.
Runkle sends a check for a new issue of the Republican and gives much praise for the worthiness of the paper.
Runkle merely discusses a private visit with Bowles.

L. G. Runkle first discusses an article with Bowles on the Smith sisters who do not pay their taxes to protest that women cannot vote. He declaims the writers of this article as unfeeling to the cause of the Smith sisters.
Runkle discussed the question of faith with Bowles.
Runkle suggests that Bowles is a little unjust to Beecher.
Runkle talks to Bowles of a mutual friend who is now married.
Runkle speaks to Bowles of an Edith Lee who is now on the stage.
L. G. Runkle jokingly writes Bowles that he should come and give him a lesson on morals on his return.
Runkle writes Bowles that he believes the Republican has convicted Beecher before the trial is over.
Russell wants to know if he must always lecture Bowles on legislation. He has noticed that Bowles speaks well of Heister Clymer of Pennsylvania.
Russell cannot understand why Bowles was angry over the Ward matter when he had already made up his mind to do what he could.
Russell had received an Ian Ialfred Townsend letter from Bowles' office and could not understand why he received it.
Russell apologizes for not having written Bowles in so long. He suggests a meeting between Bowles and Billy Collins. He says he is going to work on his book Spanish Conquest of Central America.
Russell discusses the pecuniary end of writing for the Republican with Bowles.
Russell writes Bowles that by having to keep company with a Dutch professor he must be having to expiate for some crime. Additionally, he thinks that Blaine has at last ruined himself politically.
Russell tells Bowles that the Republican supported C. E. Billings for U.S. District Judge in LA, as the Republican supported all sorts of scalawags.
Russell writes Bowles a letter telling him what he is doing, such as an accident in which he fell down the back steps.
Russell talks to Bowles of the death of a mutual friend, Denison.
Russell briefly speaks to Bowles of Washburn, Blaine, and Tilden.
Russell thinks that Bowles' reply to him on the Indian legislation was especially unkind.
Russell tells Bowles that Grant's orders contain wise words coupled with indiscreet action, as the appointment of Sheridan of Louisiana. He also says he dislikes Hayes.
Russell tells Bowles that literary men in politics become very poor. He gives Bret Hart as an example.
Russell writes Bowles that the Radicals are trying to rehabilitate Chamberlain of South Carolina.
Franklin B. Sanborn writes a poem to Samuel Bowles on his birthday - "With a Handful of Flowers."
Schurz apologizes for not having answered Bowles' last letter and for not stopping in Springfield on a recent trip.
Schurz thanks Bowles for some kind remarks in his column. Schurz discusses the outcome of the Cincinnati Convention for Republicans.

Schurz tells Bowles that he may not be able to call on him at a prescribed time. He confides in Bowles that he intends to devote himself to literary pursuits at the close of his senatorial career. He has thought of doing a political history of the United States and would like advice from Bowles as to the publisher.
Schurz discusses a Mr. Allen who might run as the "candidate for both parties."
Schurz tells Bowles that he does not consider it wise to be a demonstrator for Charles Francis Adams at this time.
Schurz agrees with Bowles that Blaine has killed himself as a candidate.
Schurz discusses the Belknap case that has changed the whole picture. He thinks Charles Francis Adams will come into the picture again but discusses a possible second choice.

Schurz discusses the intention to hold a conference at Cincinnati on Apr 27 and has among the invitations: William Cullen Bryant, President Woolsey, Governor Bullock. He wants Bowles to get Newton Booth's signature.

Schurz says that Gov. Bullock is unwilling to attend the convention, since he feels that no sufficient number of respectable Massachusetts men would attend the conference. He asks Bowles to use his influence to get him to sign.
Schurz relates to Bowles that Charles Francis Adams, Jr. has stopped by and advised Schurz not to invite Seelye to the Cincinnati movement. Schurz wants Bowles to ask him personally.
Schurz writes Bowles that he had received Bullock's signature. He acknowledges that he had received Booth's declination.
Schurz tells Bowles of the acceptance of an invitation to a certain event.
Schurz merely acknowledges a letter.
Schurz mentions that there are rumblings about himself as Secretary of the Interior.
Schurz states that the air is somewhat clearer in the Department of the Interior. He congratulates Bowles on his work in Massachusetts.
L. L. Schuyler writes Bowles that he should take a vacation for his health as she is doing for hers. She discusses the possibility of men and women working together.
Louisa Lee Schuyler sends Bowles a note including a publication issued by the State Charities Aid Association. She hopes Bowles will review the publication in the Republican.

Robert Schweichel thanks Bowles for theprivilegeof seeing his letters and of translating them into his native tongue. He tells Bowles that many German newspapers have published voluminous extracts of the letters. He hopesfor the election of Grant and Colfax as a symbol of freedom.
Harvey Whitefield Scott is impressed with Bowles' insistence on the moral side of the Bowles-Field correspondence.
Seelye tells Bowles that he is sorry to turn down an invitation. He says that he will have no part in Congressional contests. He believes politics are very corrupt at this time.
Seelye would not allow his name to be signed to the paper for a New York political meeting organized by Schurz and Bowles, since he would not be attending.
Seelye speaks to Bowles of the Speakership Contest; yet he plans to stay out of the Democratic caucus.
Seelye says that McKerr has been nominated from the caucus which was controlled by Tammany.
Seelye tells Bowles that a brother from Easthampton in Congress might stop the "Butlerizing" campaign.
Mary E. Short thanks Bowles for a notice of Mrs. Short's address.
Lynlph Slanley thanks Bowles for a copy of his book Across the Continent.
Smalley writes Bowles about various newspapers and his admiration for Whitelaw Reid as a journalist.
Smalley writes Bowles as to what to do with a Senate filled with political accomplices of Butler.
Smalley writes Bowles a friendly note, telling him about his plans as a correspondent.
Smalley discusses the professional plans of Waite and Schurz with Bowles.
George Washburn Smalley asks for a subscription to the Republican.
Phoebe Garnaut Smalley, wife of George W. Smalley, sends a note of thanks to Bowles for a picture sent to her.
G. T. Spaulding writes Bowles that he has been shown a letter in which Bowles has suggested him as a candidate for Congress. Spaulding does not want his name suggested.
A letter from James R. Spaulding expresses admiration for an article on a Henry J. Raymond. He thinks his part has been misjudged.
Spaulding asks Bowles why Maltby cannot be brought forward as a reform candidate for Congress.
George W. Stearns discusses disbelief in a libel suit against Bowles.

Stebbins talks of a trip along the west side of a California valley, which Bowles took. He wants to build a farm where the San Joaquin River connects the valley and lease areas to tenants. He hopes Bowles will make this known in the East.

Horatio Stebbins hopes Bowles' good feelings did not make him speak too kindly of Stebbins. He tells Bowles that California politics are terrible, especially the vulgarity of the press. Stebbins says that Newton Booth has been damaged due to an open tirade against Gorham. He fears that too much political blame has been put on William Chapman Ralston. He feels that in the bank situation in California an attempt has been made to cover personal responsibility by putting full blame on Ralston.
Stebbins tells Bowles that it is impossible for him to go to Amherst on a suggested trip.
Alexander Turney Steward acknowledges the pleasure of having Bowles over to dinner.
Charles Sumner acknowledges a note from Bowles.
Charles Sumner discusses an affair in the Senate, 1874.
Charles Sumner writes Bowles that Mr. Waite of Ohio has been nominated for Chief Justice and Bowles has denounced Sumner in a speech.

Allen Thayer writes Bowles that he thinks the attack of George Hoar in the Republican will work great injury to them. He says that Hoar is sensitive and fully believes that the Republican is out to break him. He says that Hoar is an honest man and asks Bowles to quit his chastisement of him.

Allen Thayer asks Bowles if it is quite the sense of justice to associate his name with thosewhomhe has opposed for many years. He points out that he has taken no active interest in politics, only in the practice of his profession.
Allen Thayer wishes to discuss an up-and-coming campaign with Bowles. He wants to see the effect the Mississippi campaign could have on the presidential election.
Allen Thayer talks of the contemptuous loss of trust by Bowles in him. Thayer says that he has aided in the campaign to defeat the Rice opponent before Adams' name was mentioned.

Allen Thayer tells Bowles that he will not ask anybody to vote for Rice at the convention, though he sees no objection to his candidacy except that he was not strong in country towns. He says he feels that Bowles has never understood that exact position.
Francis Tiffany thanks Bowles for a pamphlet containing the Field controversy letters.
Francis Tiffany writes that he is sorry about the death of Bowles' brother.
Osmond Tiffany writes Bowles a letter of introduction for Joseph Henry Rieman who wants to ask Bowles if Rev. Mr. Reed will be a good pastor.
Anna M. Tilcomb talks of the fine beginning of the Hayes administration. She briefly speaks of the Negro question and gives an intimation on women's suffrage.
Francis Amasa Walker congratulates Bowles on the result of his trial and adds a brief discussion of national politics.
Walker (George) writes Bowles that he has told Dawes that the anti-Butler campaign was enough to elect him.
Samuel Ward thanks Bowles for an expression of regret to him. Ward lists a number of bad names he has been called: pervasive, card shard, billiard expert, disreputable.
Ward apologizes for not having been aware of Bowles' illness. He discusses the fact that a lot of humbugs are in the lobby.
Annie D. Ware wants Bowles to use his influence to get her on the stage.
George C. Warr, the secretary of the Cabden Club, writes Bowles that the club is about to republish an edition on State of Land Tenure , 1870-1871. He tells Bowles that he may have a new copy.
William Washburn dislikes Bowles' paper suggesting that he would like to return to Washington.
Henry Watterson says that he and Gov. Hangen conducted an inquest on Bowles' life and character.
Henry Watterson tells Bowles that he is to orate in Indiana.
Henry Watterson compliments Bowles' integrity, calling him "dear old humbug and wretched old Yankee."
Henry Watterson wonders what is occupying Bowles now. He says he is going to Boston with Schurz and that Halstead is playing an unfriendly game with him.
Henry Watterson tells Bowles that Ohio cannot be carried.
Watterson tells Bowles he has been working since his return home. He speaks briefly of Blaine and compliments Bowles.
Henry Watterson writes a friendly letter to Bowles asking how Bowles is and discussing a recent trip.
I. Watson Webb sends Bowles a pamphlet which he wishes him to criticize honestly - irregardless of their friendship. He says that it is the duty of all editors to dispose ofcharlatans.
I. Watson Webb advises Bowles that in looking over the pamphlet of Col. Canjun's that Mr. Kane was not dead but lost a leg.

Thurlow Weed regrets that he cannot leave Albany before Tuesday, which will make it too late for him to confer with friends. He tells Bowles that his and Greeley's views coincide on the question of a certain Senator.
David Ames Wells states that the notice of the position of the New York Supreme Court on stock certificates puts him in an altogether wary position.

Wells discusses Garfield's responses on political issues. He mentions the United States Supreme Court's decision on taxation of railroads and state boards. He thinks the latter knocks the supremacy out of the New England tax system.
D. A.Wells thinks that he has not a ghost of achancefor Congress.
John Wells encloses a newspaper clipping in his letter to Bowles on judicial scandals and a condemnation of the sensational style of the paper.
John Wells is dissatisfied with the tone of the Republican. He says that he and Bowles have different planes of thought; he hopes that they can discuss it in person sometime.
Horace White praises the Republican and wants it sent to him in Rome. He says, after having been in Rome, that he believes the Papacy is a fraud; now he is in sympathy with Bismarck.

Horace White tells Bowles that he has received a letter of his. He tells Bowles that Browne is justified in his course, since there is no other. He intimates that two suggestions have been made lately referring to Bryant's purchase of the Post. He thinks that the selection of Washburn would be the mere prolongation of Grant.

John Greenleaf Whittier writes Charles Sumner a thank you for his help on the Cuban difficulty. Whittier speaks of the terrible butcheries occurring in France with the Commune. He says that the intelligent Republicans of Spain hate this.

Whittier writes John H. Cook thanking him for a copy of an eloquent tribute to the memory of William F. Bartlett. Hehopesa statue will be set up on the banks of the Merrimac at the place of his birth.
Charles Wesley Willard is thinking Bowles for his fight for freedom of the newspapers. He says that such decisions as Judge Endicott's will not breed libel suits.
C. W. Willard tells Bowles that it is difficult to give the names of people who really want reform.
Henry Wilson writes Bowles for a copy of a letter to which a Mr. Brown has referred.

Henry Wilson thanks Bowles for a note and for not assailing him in the newspaper for actions at Philadelphia. He thanks Bowles for his help in Philadelphia and believes that the hour is at hand for a united party.
Robert Charles Winthrop says that he has received a favor from Bowles and a copy of History of Western Massachusetts.

Thomas C. Zimmerman writes Schuyler Colfax asking him to write Bowles a letter on Professor William Evans, an eminent elocutionist. On the reverse side, Colfax recommends that Bowles follow Zimmerman's instructions on Evans.
Incomplete correspondence
An unsigned notation describes the ethics of the bar in the nineteenth century as leaving much to be desired.
R. A. C. (unidentified) says to Bowles that if he examines the Republican platform for 1864 that he will find a plank or two on reform.
The letter is unsigned and incomplete. The person is going abroad and shows a concern for national politics.
Most of this letter is missing, and it is unsigned, although the handwriting is like that of Anna M. Tilcomb.
Lucy F. G. Writes Bowles a letter of thanks for their correspondence.
A fragment of a Bartlett letter is in the collection concerning his taking a seat in Washington.
A man with the initials H. J. G. acknowledges Bowles' letter and says that he may not be able to see Bowles in Boston.
An unsigned poem on the theme"Flowers"is included.
David Dudley Field correspondence
George Jones, newspaper publisher, believes Bowles has managed the Bowles-Field controversy with sagacity.

Whitelaw Reid writes Bowles taking a stand close to that of Field, that one should be especially careful as to whether a suit is a libel or not. However, Reid would like to devote some columns to the publication of the Field letters. Reid thinks Bowles should make public any defamation in the character of David Dudley Field.
Charles Dudley Warner congratulates Bowles; yet he points out that Field is smart. He expresses pride in Bowles as a journalist.
Egbert Watson writes Bowles of knowing Field in childhood as one who was able to use his friends and associates.
E. W. B. Canning, a townsman of Field, is in agreement with Bowles.

W. W. Rice writes Bowles that he never knew such a correspondence as the Bowles-Field one to be profitable. Rice agrees with Bowles, but he thinks that Field's argument is plausible. He thinks that Bowles should look more into the legal profession.
William Henry Brewer congratulates Bowles on his stand with Field and thinks that this point is often a problem of most professional people.

Julius Hawley Seelye is in sympathy with Bowles; he suggests that the question is not "whether a villain should always berefusedfor a client, but whether his villainy should be held up as not heinous and as worthy of the solemn approval of justice."
Whitelaw Reid reports to Bowles that he was unable to superviseprintingof the Field material but thanks Bowles for the power of justice.
Dawes congratulates Bowles on his management of the Bowles-Field controversy and is glad that Bowles did not enter a technical argument with Field.
Schluemback congratulates Bowles on the liberating quality of the Field correspondence.
William A. Seaver congratulates Bowles on his justice and ability in the Field-Bowles controversy.
W. A. Steasul writes Bowles a congratulatory note on the Field affair.
G. Boutwell states he believes that the Fields are "worsted" in the encounter of Bowles-Field.
C. C. Chaffee writes a congratulatory note to Bowles on the Field case.
R. Hawkins agrees with Bowles on the Field case.
James Reed Spalding writes a congratulatory note to Bowles on his stand with Field.
C. A. Runkle is pleased with Bowles' stand against Field; however, he wishes that he had gonefurtherin the bribery question.
George Walker writes Bowles a congratulatory letter on his stand in the Field affair.
An anonymous letter reports on what a fellow passenger on a train said of Field with the indication that Bowles should have pressed more.
Bowles receives an unsigned congratulatory note on the Bowles-Field correspondence.
John Rogers writes David Dudley Field accusing him of collaboration with Judge Barnard.
S. Sheaven writes a congratulatory letter to Bowles.
Charles Dudley Warnerpointsout to Bowles that he has caused quite a row. Warner discusses the affair with some agreement with Bowles.
Gardner L., who knew Field in his youth, congratulates Bowles.
P. M. Reed, a lawyer from Old Lyme, writes Bowles that he regards Field's position as untenable and wrong.
Edwin M. Stone expresses interest in the moralissue of the Field controversy.
Washington Gladden writes Bowles that he is in agreement with him on his stand in the Field affair. Gladden wrote an article for the NY Independent on the subject.
Charles Rice sends a complimentary letter to Bowles for his stand with Field.
Charles John Reed brings out the point to Bowles that Fisk and Gould have the right to be defended by law.
Alexander Hyde thanks Bowles for the favor to the journalistic profession.
Charles Allen writes Bowles that a case can be so dishonest that a lawyer will suffer if he tries it in court.
C. H. Muff is in agreement with Bowles on the Field correspondence.
Samuel Wolcott praises Bowles for his stand on the moral issue in the Bowles-Field controversy.
Bigelow writes Bowles that the D. D. Field affair should have been exposed long before and is sorry that New York couldn't have done it.
C. F. Adams, Jr., writes Bowles that he thinks that Field received very little from Bowles and that Bowles' correspondence was the least he should have had.
Lewis B. Parsues is pleased with Bowles' stand in the Bowles-Field controversy.
Billings writes Bowles a congratulatory letter on the Field case.
A scrap of paper from George P. Rand was found in the Field correspondence.
A list of the Field correspondence is enclosed in the collection - probably made by Bowles.

did.unittitle: Mayoralty contest of 1873
Walker tells Bowles that perhaps he is right in not running for mayor.
Clark W. Bryan writes Bowles admiring him for his stand in not running for mayor.
A letter from George Walker to Bowles urges him to run for mayor.
A letter from Herbert Lawrence Bridgman congratulates Bowles on his stand as to the election for mayor in Springfield.
Alexander H. Bullock discussed an invitation to dine at a club in Springfield with Bowles and other Springfield men.
E. B. Gillette regrets that Bowles will not run for mayor.
The collection contains nineteen newspaper clippings on Bowles' stand in the mayoralty contest.
A petition is drawn up by the citizens of Springfield, urging Bowles to run for mayor.
The New York jail episode
Edm. C. Dwight expresses regret that Bowles was treated in such a way but suggests that the incident brought out the worst of the accused.
Henry Martyn Field expresses his rage over Bowles being seized.
Henry Wilson Corbett expresses disgust at the way Bowles has been treated and hopes that Bowles will vindicate himself by exposing them.
Robert Bonner expresses unhappiness over the dishonor done Bowles in the jail episode.
Joseph Roswell Hawley expresses delight that now Bowles can see how many friends he has, although he is unhappy with his being put in jail.
J. P. Putnam writes a letter expressing his outrage at Bowles having been jailed.
William Augustus Stearns acknowledges that the treatment of Bowles by Fisk was dastardly.
Thomas Russell gives Bowles an invitation to dine with a number of outstanding people who want to attest to Bowles' character.

John Pierce jokingly discusses Bowles writing a book on his prison experiences. The letter takes advantage of Bowles having been in jail. It begins, "Dear Jailbird." Pierce advises Bowles to quit attacking people in his pages.
Donald Grant Mitchell (Ik Marvel) expresses indignation at Bowles' treatment in New York.
A brochure is contained in this packet with a group of names of people who want to honor the character of Bowles.
The Death of Samuel Bowles
George W. Smalley is distressed to hear that Bowles is ill and suggests that he go to Europe.
Musgrave writes Bowles of a letter received from Halstead. He wants to keep posted on Bowles' improvement.
M. E. B. (not identified) hopes the change of weather will not bring ill effects to Bowles.
E. B. Haskell has heard of Bowles' ill health and says that nature must fit him with a perishable casket.
James A. Briggs expresses happiness at hearing of Bowles' improvement.
Joseph Pulitzer expresses sorrow at Bowles' illness and delight at his seeming recovery.
James D. Colt says any man who can express views on the senatorial contest must be well on the way to recovery. He is happy that Bowles has taken a turn for the best.
J. M. Dalgell sends heartfelt joy at Bowles' restoration to partial health.

Henry Cooley had called at Bowles' office and was informed of his illness. His point was to tell Bowles that he had come into harmony with his views and felt that the Republican had followed the right course.
William Orton tells Bowles that he has read of his severe illness and expresses desire for his complete recovery.
J. Brady writes Bowles that nothing except duties to be performed prevent him from going to see Bowles with Musgrave.
Weir Mitchell prescribes a certain beer for Bowles. He is happy to hear of Bowles' gain in health.
Benjamin F. Bowles hopes that his note is no intrusion; however, he says that though they differ politically, he thinks that it would be a pity if he could not express his bereavement.

Miscellaneous material on the death of Samuel Bowles
A letter to a Mrs. Leonard from M. Noylad says that he does not know any of the family except the father; yet he hopes someone will express his feelings to them.
A letter from H. D. Lloyd to Miss Titcomb tells of some things that might be done to save Bowles' life.
Charles Nordhoff writes a Miss Clark that he has word that Bowles is somewhat better. He gives information on the president as being firm against powerfully combined forces.
Charles D. Warner tells E. F. Hayes that he had planned to be present at the funeral itself until announced that it was private.
A letter addressed to no one, signed with theinitialsA. P. L., laments the death of Samuel Bowles II.
Isaac H. Brosseler writes E. F. Hayes that he shall be present at the memorial service.
A letter to E. F. Hayes from Hooker says that he shall have to be in attendance upon the Supreme Court of Bridgeport, and he is very sad that he cannot attend the funeral.
Berry H. Bailey writes a letter to the publishers of the Republican enclosing a money order for his subscription for a year; he also wants the issue on Bowles' death.

Four announcements of Bowles' memorial service are in this collection. There are four programs from the memorial service. Some calling cards to Bowles during his illness are included. There are two copies of the Charles Dudley Warner reading at the memorial service. An appreciation from the city of Springfield for Samuel Bowles II is in the collection.

Two copies of a newspaper article, "The Moral Limits of Professional Service," were included in this packet of letters.
A newspaper article is contained in this packet concerning the marriage of the eldest daughter of Cyrus W. Field. A second article also appears on this subject.
The Travelers Record is included with a tribute to Samuel Bowles on his pending death.
A clipping concerning the Beecher trial is included.
A newspaper article on Lessie Goodell Gustafson appears in this section.
A large group of petitioners desire Bowles to dine with them due to respect for his character. This letter contains a petition. (missing 2/1/79)
A receipt of Mrs. Bowles for Kelsey and Allen - purchase of soap - is in the collection.
Fourteen copies of printed correspondence to the director of the Boston and Chicago Gold Mining Co. offering stock for sale are included in the collection.
The program for a complimentary reception to Schuyler Colfax and friends is in the collection.

A trust calling for the organization of a new party is included in this Bowles packet. A meeting is to be held in Worcester in December. Among the signatories are Samuel Hooker, Charles Francis Adams, Sr., George Boutwell, George Bliss, H. L. Dawes, and Samuel Bowles.
Printed request forSamuelBowles to be the guest of honor at a dinner attesting to his character and Bowles' declination of the event are in the collection.

Six Chinese companies in San Francisco, California, invite Samuel Bowles, Schuyler Colfax, William Bross, and Albert D. Richardson to a complimentary dinner.
A statement of the Republican letters appointing Bowles to deliver a trust to the President of the Senate, among the signatures are those of Robert C. Winthrop, George Bliss, and Rufus Bullock.
Two menus for a complimentary dinner given for Samuel Bowles at Springfield
